Thanks for the update!

The Ocenstore libhttp package is known to be very rough; really just a
placeholder or starting point for what we'd need. (Note that there's
also an alternative 'libhttp2' package in OceanStore, but it seemed both
unused in their other code and more elaborate, so I haven't tried
to use it yet.)

The TCP response ordering capabilities to aSocketInputStream only seem
necessary if you have multiple threads reading from the same socket -- which
I think can, and probably should, be avoided.

I'm looking forward to seeing the test results.

I like the BuildDesign proposal; please move forward with creating
that structure for a new module on the sourceforge CVS. However,
please use the module name of "ArchiveOpenCrawler" (instead of
"Web-crawler").

Thanks!

- Gordon

----- Original Message -----
From: G.B.Reddy
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 11:04 AM
Subject: [archive-crawler] Status !!


Gordon,

I am presently working on the SEDA socket overhead determination work. I will get the results in the next two days. Some initial
insights into it are
- Oceanstore manages both Tx and Rx in a single stage.
- It just holds the responses in memory only. It does not write into tmp files if they are huge.
- TCP response reordering is done by using the seda.sandStorm.lib.aSocket.aSocketInputStream class which reorders packets according
to the ATcpInPacket sequence number.

The test that will be done :
- Port the downloader code ( which we had written earlier during the java nio performance tests ) to SEDA framework and use the
OceanStore library for HTTP fetching. The same tests that we did for the downloader will be repeated in this oceanstore setup. We
are removing some oceanstore code to make it similar. The result of this test would tell us the percentage of overhead imposed by
the SEDA framework.


We are also done with the JAnt packaging scripts. It uses the present CVS structure itself. I shall create the proposed CVS
structure after you approve it. Today we have put the cronjob for testing the web hosting part of nightly builds. We shall enable it
for all tomorrow. As of now, only the last nightly build will be available for download. More changes need to be made for hosting
every nightly build of a week.

Thanks,
Reddy
